summary: then bow your head in the house of god
title: then bow your head in the house of god
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2HFnys7

by NeverNooitNiet

It was stupid of him, though. And dangerous— he still had the little scorched spots from that time in the 1940s to prove it. But he’d slathered the scaly soles of his feet in sunscreen, and then wrapped that slippery mess in three pairs of thick hiking socks, before forcing that into his thickest-soled pair of boots, so he reckoned he’d be all right, for a little while, providing he didn’t touch anything. Or step on a saint, or something.

The world fails to end, and Crowley visits a cathedral.

by ColorfulTaper

In this Alternate Universe the Winchester’s meet the mysterious Magnum sisters. When John goes missing Dean calls on not only Sam but Kara and Lyra as well. Raised in the life of hunting the Magnum sisters have their own dark family secrets. Secrets that follow them to this day. During their travels the 4 hunters discover shocking similarities in their pasts and struggle to come to terms with the fates determined for them. Love, betrayal, sacrifice, and death plague their every move. Can the Winchester’s and Magnum’s find their purpose in this doomed, sad little world? Will they be able to protect each other from the demons and monsters that haunt the night?

blog.title: Supernatural Opinion + Commentary
blog.description: Follow if you like obnoxiously long posts. I make best efforts to post original content every Sunday/Monday.

summary: Was Crowley the worst or the best demon?
title: Was Crowley the worst or the best demon?
body:
*SPOILERS SEASONS 1-13*

First, the argument that Crowley was the worst thing ever to happen to demonkind. 

In the beginning of the show, demons had a leader: Azazel. Since 1973 (at least), he was the man with the plan, and led the lower orders of demons with the eventual goal of freeing Lucifer from Hell. They shared his vision, but that’s only a small part of why they followed him. Mainly, it was because he was powerful. The only reason demons will follow a leader is they’re scared not to. When Azazel bit the dust, Lilith took his place, and after Lilith, their god had returned—Lucifer. Demons were one of Sam and Dean’s biggest threats because they were organized and mission-oriented.

After Lucifer and Michael were trapped in Hell in Swan Song, everyone fell into disarray. However, as a civil war played out in Heaven, Hell had no such problems. Obviously, the next in line to rule would be Ramiel, the second-oldest Prince of Hell. Yet when Crowley offered Ramiel the throne, he turned it down. Whaat? In a show of unorthodox behavior, Ramiel turned the kingship over to Crowley. With all the living princes, plus Cain, uninterested, Crowley took the opportunity to seize the throne. Crowley’s problem was he just wasn’t scary enough to legitimize himself. He was always going to have issues holding onto his throne, and that’s why he went to such lengths to open Purgatory with Cas in Season 6. Abbadon and even Deanmon had more legitimate claims to Hell’s throne than he did. 

When Crowley almost got cured in Sacrifice, his character fundamentally changed, much to the detriment of Hell. But even before his pivot, Crowley wasn’t the kind of leader Hell needed. Demons were designed to be a disposable army, not a bureaucracy. Crossroads Demons have their place in Hell, but not every demon is meant to be a Crossroads Demon. It made sense that Sam and Dean saw Abaddon as the much larger threat, because she was. Who’s more likely to lead Hell back to its former glory, a bored bureaucrat or a mad general? If Crowley had never come into power, the demons would have had to spend only a few years in chaos before Abaddon arrived to take her place as queen (provided Sam and Dean didn’t manage to kill her). If they had, would demons simply be running around freely as in early Season 3? I don’t think that would have been worse (for Hell) than them hanging around Hell bored out of their minds, dreaming up ways to double-cross Crowley. From sentimentally saving Cas in Stuck in the Middle (With You) to promising to shut the gates of Hell forever, Crowley left an awesome legacy, but not one that benefited his own kind. 

On the other hand, Crowley could have been demons’ savior.

Remember when he said in Season 5 that after Lucifer won the war against Heaven he would kill all the demons? That’s a good guess. If Lucifer can ever be said to be happy, it’s when he’s around his closest kin—the other archangels, his dad, Jack. Humans are “broken, flawed abortions,” and once-human demons are if anything worse. Lucifer doesn’t care about them. 

So did Crowley play an appreciable role in stopping Lucifer’s victory in Season 5? Yes. If he hadn’t given Sam and Dean the Colt, they probably would have gone on a lengthly wild-goose-chase looking for it as in The End. Crowley was also invaluable when it came to finding the Four Horsemen. Well, two of them, anyway. When time was of the essence, Sam, Dean, and Bobby didn’t know where to start looking for them. Not to mention the tip-off Crowley gave them about the Croatoan virus distribution. 

Crowley’s one mess-up that sticks out is saving Lucifer from the cage in Season 12. There are many things that don’t make sense in Season 12 that I’ll have to get to sometime, and Crowley suddenly making stupid decisions is one of them. Whatever, he’s allowed to make one mistake in his life, right? He did try to make up for it with his final sacrifice, and maybe it’s because I love him, but I forgive him. 

Thus, Crowley may have run demonkind into the ground, contributing heavily to their current irrelevancy, but he did save all their lives.

In the end, was Crowley the worst or the best? Did he ruin the demons or save them? You decide.

In a show of unorthodox behavior, Ramiel turned the kingship over to Crowley. With all the living princes, plus Cain, uninterested, Crowley took the opportunity to seize the throne. Crowley’s problem was he just wasn’t scary enough to legitimize himself. He was always going to have issues holding onto his throne, and that’s why he went to such lengths to open Purgatory with Cas in Season 6. Abbadon and even Deanmon had more legitimate claims to Hell’s throne than he did. 

When Crowley almost got cured in Sacrifice, his character fundamentally changed, much to the detriment of Hell. But even before his pivot, Crowley wasn’t the kind of leader Hell needed. Demons were designed to be a disposable army, not a bureaucracy. Crossroads Demons have their place in Hell, but not every demon is meant to be a Crossroads Demon. It made sense that Sam and Dean saw Abaddon as the much larger threat, because she was. Who’s more likely to lead Hell back to its former glory, a bored bureaucrat or a mad general? If Crowley had never come into power, the demons would have had to spend only a few years in chaos before Abaddon arrived to take her place as queen (provided Sam and Dean didn’t manage to kill her). If they had, would demons simply be running around freely as in early Season 3? I don’t think that would have been worse (for Hell) than them hanging around Hell bored out of their minds, dreaming up ways to double-cross Crowley. From sentimentally saving Cas in Stuck in the Middle (With You) to promising to shut the gates of Hell forever, Crowley left an awesome legacy, but not one that benefited his own kind. 

On the other hand, Crowley could have been demons’ savior.

Remember when he said in Season 5 that after Lucifer won the war against Heaven he would kill all the demons? That’s a good guess. If Lucifer can ever be said to be happy, it’s when he’s around his closest kin—the other archangels, his dad, Jack. Humans are “broken, flawed abortions,” and once-human demons are if anything worse. Lucifer doesn’t care about them. 

So did Crowley play an appreciable role in stopping Lucifer’s victory in Season 5? Yes. If he hadn’t given Sam and Dean the Colt, they probably would have gone on a lengthly wild-goose-chase looking for it as in The End. Crowley was also invaluable when it came to finding the Four Horsemen. Well, two of them, anyway. When time was of the essence, Sam, Dean, and Bobby didn’t know where to start looking for them. Not to mention the tip-off Crowley gave them about the Croatoan virus distribution. 

Crowley’s one mess-up that sticks out is saving Lucifer from the cage in Season 12. There are many things that don’t make sense in Season 12 that I’ll have to get to sometime, and Crowley suddenly making stupid decisions is one of them. Whatever, he’s allowed to make one mistake in his life, right? He did try to make up for it with his final sacrifice, and maybe it’s because I love him, but I forgive him. 

Thus, Crowley may have run demonkind into the ground, contributing heavily to their current irrelevancy, but he did save all their lives.

In the end, was Crowley the worst or the best? Did he ruin the demons or save them? You decide.
trail.content:
*SPOILERS SEASONS 1-13*

First, the argument that Crowley was the worst thing ever to happen to demonkind. 

In the beginning of the show, demons had a leader: Azazel. Since 1973 (at least), he was the man with the plan, and led the lower orders of demons with the eventual goal of freeing Lucifer from Hell. They shared his vision, but that’s only a small part of why they followed him. Mainly, it was because he was powerful. The only reason demons will follow a leader is they’re scared not to. When Azazel bit the dust, Lilith took his place, and after Lilith, their god had returned—Lucifer. Demons were one of Sam and Dean’s biggest threats because they were organized and mission-oriented.

summary:
I feel like Good Omens is about Aziraphale and Crowley the same way Silence of the Lambs is about Hannibal Lecter.
Anthony...
body:
I feel like Good Omens is about Aziraphale and Crowley the same way Silence of the Lambs is about Hannibal Lecter.

Anthony Hopkins won best actor despite only being on screen for a set amount of time. Reading the book is the same. Some characters just have presence. They leave an impression on your mind/heart/soul.

The same can be said about Aziraphale and Crowley and their interactions in Good Omens. You enjoy the whole thing thoroughly and love all the characters but when you tell people about it you focus on the angel and the demon.

Some characters are more than words on paper and images in a mind’s eye.

Keep in mind I am biased: I reread either Hannibal or SotL almost yearly and Good Omens is my favourite book ever. But there are other examples and everyone has to have at least one of those.

summary: R.I.P Supernatural
body:
R.I.P Supernatural

Just because the show ends, the fandom never will. I will always continue to watch supernatural, even if it ends. Yes, it’s sad the show is ending, but we always can rewatch all 15 (once it comes out) seasons just like they are brand new! I have watched supernatural for as long as I can remember, it’s been apart of my life for a long time, it’s helped me through tough times in my life, hell, it saved my life, I had bad deppression and I felt like shit all the time, supernatural was my escape. Supernatural will always be here when we need it, it won’t be new seasons but we still have it forever, plus it’ll be a chance to explore new shows!

Sorry for this semi long.. rant? I don’t know if it’s a rant or not.

Love you all!

❤💜💙💚💛❤💜💙💚💛❤💜💙💚💛❤💜

summary: Balance
title: Balance
body:
My Ask | My Ko-Fi | My Ao3 | Requests always welcome! 

Rated T. 2.5k. A/C. Just some domestic sweetness. Aziraphale isn’t good with children, not like Crowley is, like Crowley always has been. But he tries his best.

“That’s alright, just like that,” Crowley said, smiling as he leaned back, and Aziraphale kept his book loosely in his lap as he watched Crowley work. Liam had his arms outstretched as he walked slowly along the bar, his gaze forward. “No, no, see, you’re going on your tiptoes again – you don’t need to. You’ve got the whole of your sole to help you balance, lad, so your toes and your heel… That’s it.”

“How can you do it so fast?” Liam demanded, and he stumbled, but Crowley moved to catch him by the hand before he could tip too far the other way, letting him catch his balance again.

The children had been watching Crowley fix some of the tiling on the Halifax family’s roof on the other side of Chesterton-Burnleigh, and they’d been mystified by the way Crowley had moved so fast back and forth over the support beams and even over the railing on the edges of their balconies. Aziraphale would love to be able to chalk it up to his demonic grace, that perhaps he had his wings invisibly outstretched to assist him in balancing, but he knew that wasn’t the case: Crowley really was that comfortable on his fleet feet, balancing on thin beams and railings, and now he had set up a wooden beam on the picnic green beside the pond for them to try their own balance on. The grass here was thick and littered with daisies, and would provide a good deal of padding if they fell, beyond Crowley’s own little twists of magic.

He remembered, the body Crowley had had before this one. He’d lost it in… Oh, what year was it? 1831, he thought, that he’d been discorporated, and he’d only had it for sixty years or so. He preferred – like Aziraphale – to wear a man’s body, as a rule[1], but he’d worn a woman’s body, then. He’d been kicked by a horse, Aziraphale thought, that was what had ended it…

He’d been a nursemaid for quite a few families, before he’d gone on to teach at a girls’ school for ten years or so. He had always enjoyed the work, and Aziraphale had always thought he would be corrupting the children, but he never did, especially. The children were always very happy and healthy, and he was always very careful with them, even as he went about his usual duties. It was the best way, he always said at the time, for a young woman to remain unmarried and not in threat of such proposals, but Aziraphale had never really believed that.

Crowley could go unnoticed no matter whom or what he wore.

“It’s just practice,” Crowley was saying gently. “You get a sense for it.”

Liam came to the end of the bar, taking a slow step down, and Crowley turned to gesture for young Lisa, who was the end of the line.

She crossed her arms over her chest. “It looks quite dangerous,” she said.

“It isn’t dangerous,” Crowley said, shaking his head. Aziraphale watched the way he moved. It came so instinctively to him, it always had: he leaned down just slightly, that him and Lisa were on a more similar level, but his body language was open and casual. Aziraphale wouldn’t have thought to do that, he didn’t think – or maybe he would have crouched, and Crowley said the children hated it when one did that. “Look, you’ve seen Liam, Stephanie, and Nathaniel do it, and when Nick fell, I caught him, didn’t I?”

“Yeah, but he’s small,” Lisa said. She was a rather large little girl, round where her sister was more athletic, and she looked rather anxious. “He’s not nearly as heavy as I am.”

Crowley smiled, and it was a warm, gentle smile, softly paternal in its aspect, and Aziraphale exhaled quietly at the sight of it. “Lisa, you are not heavy. You’ve seen me carry big sheets of glass, the stone for the benches… Darling, you’re a bag of feathers compared to all that.”

Lisa didn’t look convinced, biting down upon her lower lip, and Aziraphale hesitated, but then he set a bookmark on his page, taking a few steps forward.

“Why don’t I show you, dear?” he asked, and Lisa turned to look up at him. Aziraphale felt himself stiffen slightly, uncertain, but then Lisa gave an anxious smile, and nodded her head. She was the only one of the children who visited here he really felt he understood, although that was hardly saying much: he wasn’t very good with children, much as he tried his best, and he knew that, but Lisa didn’t seem to mind especially, and would sometimes come and sit down next to him whilst Crowley led the other children in an activity, or when she grew disinterested in Crowley’s lessons on one subject or other.

“You can’t do it,” Stephanie said as Aziraphale delicately toed off his loafers.

“And why is that, young lady?” Aziraphale asked as Crowley smiled at him, leaning forward and taking hold of his hand, bringing it up to his mouth and kissing the back of his knuckles.

“You’re old,” Stephanie said. “And— And—”

“Big?” Aziraphale asked, somewhat archly.

Stephanie closed her mouth. Aziraphale heard Lisa giggle behind him.

“You will catch me?” he asked, somewhat uncertainly.

“You probably won’t fall,” Crowley said, and Aziraphale laughed as he stepped up the wooden stair Crowley had laid beside the beam. It wasn’t so far off the ground – only a little higher than four feet – but he did feel somewhat unbalanced as he set one sole upon the beam, stretching out his arms and letting Crowley release his hand.

“Could you fix someone’s roof, Mr Fell?” Nick asked.

“Oh, goodness, no,” Aziraphale said, resisting the urge to shake his head, because he knew he would topple if he did that. He wanted to throw out his wings to assist him, but he didn’t wish to cheat, as it were: he was rather unsteady as he moved along the beam, rather slowly, compared to the children, but Crowley was smiling up at him as he walked alongside. “No, I fear Anthony far exceeds me in most practical skills.”

“That’s not true,” Crowley murmured. “Ezra can make bindings for books from scratch. Spins his goldwork and everything.”

“What’s goldwork?” Liam asked.

“You spin metals into thin threads,” Ezra said, focusing forward as he drew his next foot forward. “You can embroider with them, then – some books take well to embroidery to decorate covers, especially leather and cloth covers, but it’s very good for the binding, too, where one might stitch the pages. Golden or silver thread is quite hardwearing, of course.”

“Wow,” Liam said. Aziraphale felt his lips twitch as he finally came to the end of the beam. He’d had a few wobbles, but he hadn’t fallen—

Well.

Until now.

He turned to meet Crowley’s gaze, and the demon gave a slight inclination of his head: Aziraphale squeezed his eyes rather tightly shut as he let himself tip to the side, doing his best not to let out a yelp as he felt his foot come away from the bar, but he knew Crowley would catch him, he knew—

Crowley’s arms were strong as they encircled him, catching at the backs of his thighs and his back, and Aziraphale let out a breathless sound, reaching up and touching the side of Crowley’s neck. Crowley leaned in, kissing his nose, and Aziraphale laughed quietly, leaning his head on Crowley’s shoulder as he exhaled.

“See?” Crowley said, winking at Lisa. “Light as a feather.”

She did look much more confident now, at least. Aziraphale could see the light shining in her eyes and the way she was bouncing on her heels, and he felt himself smile slightly as he stood delicately back to his feet, moving to retrieve his shoes.

Lisa hurried forward, and Aziraphale stepped to the side, but to his surprise she threw her arms about his waist, hugging him very tightly. “Oh,” he said, awkwardly – but gently – patting the top of her head, brushing the blue silk of her Alice band as he did so, and he smiled.

“Thank you, Mr Fell,” she mumbled against the wool vest over his belly.

“Oh, my dear, it’s no trouble at all, come now.” He looked at Crowley, who raised his eyebrows and shrugged his shoulders slightly, but his smile was encouraging. Aziraphale delicately patted her shoulder, and she leaned back, beaming up at him, before she stepped toward the beam and removed her little ballet slippers.

It was—

He hadn’t been hugged by a child in an awfully long time, he didn’t think. He wasn’t sure in how many years, but not for… In the mid-19th century, perhaps, when Crowley was asleep – he’d taken up at the Hyacinth and Vine, the discreet little gentleman’s club in London, much more than he had, and he believed he’d fetched some young boy’s cat from a tree whilst walking out to the club of an evening. Poor thing had been beside himself, if he recalled.

This was somewhat more—

Significant, he supposed it felt.

They had been here for several months, now. Adam had visited twice, and that had been nice – they’d actually rather begun being his godfathers, in the year since the Apocalypse hadn’t happened, and he was a pleasant boy, kind, intelligent, but he was rather…

Crowley would no doubt chide him for calling the boy rough-and-tumble. Aziraphale didn’t know what the more modern parlance might be. But he didn’t especially need anybody’s support or comfort, and although he often asked Aziraphale questions, he didn’t ordinarily wait for an answer.

These children, though, they did listen to him, particularly when they asked for him to explain something. They could be a little rude, of course – Stephanie in particular had a rather startling tendency to blurt out precisely what was on her mind, regardless of how thoughtless it might be, and young Nathaniel tried too hard to be clever, sometimes with a view to being unkind, but… They weren’t nasty children, not at all. They were generally thoughtful, and generally gentle.

He recalled when Crowley had taught at that girls’ school – those young ladies had been vicious little demons in their own right, even without his careful tutelage. He liked children, Aziraphale knew. He was good with them, and they liked him: they liked that he was funny and erudite, and they liked how neatly he explained things, how he saw things on their level…

Aziraphale wasn’t all that good at such things. He condescended without meaning to, or got confused as to what the children did or didn’t know, or tried too hard. But, Crowley…

“There you go, my girl!” Crowley said, clapping his hands together, and Lisa laughed as she stepped on very graceful feet down from the beam – she really did have nothing to worry about. She was an incredibly dainty girl, with a grace that did remind Aziraphale of the way things used to be, seventy years ago, ninety…

She beamed at Aziraphale, and he smiled right back at her.

♔ ☩ ♔ ☩ ♔ ☩ ♔

Later on, when the children had gone home, he sat at one of the stools on the kitchen island, watching Crowley’s fingers as he delicately worked upon the pastry, twisting two threads of the stuff about the edge of a bramble pie.

“Crowley,” Aziraphale asked.

“Yeah?”

“With— With Young Warlock,” Aziraphale said quietly, keeping his hands up from the counter and away from the flour dusting it, “you sent Ashtoreth. In your place, I mean, as I sent Francis.”

“Ye-es,” Crowley said, raising an expectant eyebrow.

“But— Well, my dear, you were a nursemaid. For nearly fifty years! And that was without teaching at that boarding school, too.”

“Oh, that was years ago,” Crowley scoffed, his tone dismissive. “Children were different, then.”

“But these children are just the same, and you’re good with them,” Aziraphale said. “Teaching them this morning, you did so well with them. They adore you. I don’t mean to disparage Ashtoreth’s abilities, but had you nannied himself, you know, you’d have been— You’d have been at quite the advantage, you know, you could have…”

“We wanted it to be equal,” Crowley said. “Our influence.”

“Yes,” Aziraphale allowed.

“And I never—” Crowley furrowed his brow, pressing his lips together. “Ashtoreth was comfortable, going all in for that… Hell stuff. You know, telling him to praise Lucifer and what-not, and telling him to be nasty and cruel. What do I want to be telling a kid to do that for? She was just as— What is it, as Francis was? Over-the-top, it means.”

“Superlative?”

“Superlative,” Crowley said, nodding his head. “Yeah. I couldn’t have been like that.”

“You seem— My dear, you seem ever so happy. So in your element, with these children.”

“I am,” Crowley murmured, his lip twitching slightly, and Aziraphale reached out, drawing his fingers gently over Crowley’s chin, tracing the jut of bone there. “Can’t exactly win that Lisa Turpin over, though. She’s your girl through and through, Mr Fell.”

“Oh, I don’t know about that, Mr Crowley,” Aziraphale murmured, touching his thumb to the base of Crowley’s lip as Crowley looked at him with warmth in his yellow eyes, but he felt himself smile, felt the sense of warmth the idea evoked. “They’re such… They’re such lovely children. I just wish I had your grace with them.”

“You just need to let them come to you,” Crowley said. “Like cats.”

“A lot of cats find me overbearing,” Aziraphale said.

“Yeah,” Crowley said. “This advice is two birds with one stone, angel.”

Aziraphale let out an indignant huff, but Crowley leaned his chin right into Aziraphale’s palm, showing his teeth when he smiled again. “You know,” Aziraphale said, “and I don’t say this in terms of the, ah, the near future, but… A lot of retirees, they foster.”

“Something to think about,” Crowley said quietly, kissing the meat at the heel of Aziraphale’s palm. “Do you want to watch something? I’ll bring the television up to the bedroom.”

“What have you in mind?”

“Star Trek. The one with the whales, I picked it up on video.”

“We saw that in the cinema only a few years back.”

“Yeah, I know,” Crowley said.

Aziraphale considered this for a moment, his fingers stroking at the base of Crowley’s throat, feeling the smoothness of the skin. For just a moment, they were outside Eden, and Crowley was but a mess of roping coils in his lap, his scaled chin resting in Aziraphale’s palm. That was ever so long ago, and yet equally, it was just yesterday.

He nodded, with a small smile, and he withdrew his hand, that Crowley might return to his work.

It was a good night.

Peaceful, quiet.

They were at home together, and this was the new routine.

[1] Although, they would each freely admit, this mattered very little, as either of them could alter their appearance quite entirely on the head of a pin, if they wanted to, but it was the premise of the thing.

My Ask | My Ko-Fi | My Ao3 | Requests always welcome! 

Rated T. 2.5k. A/C. Just some domestic sweetness. Aziraphale isn’t good with children, not like Crowley is, like Crowley always has been. But he tries his best.

“That’s alright, just like that,” Crowley said, smiling as he leaned back, and Aziraphale kept his book loosely in his lap as he watched Crowley work. Liam had his arms outstretched as he walked slowly along the bar, his gaze forward. “No, no, see, you’re going on your tiptoes again – you don’t need to. You’ve got the whole of your sole to help you balance, lad, so your toes and your heel… That’s it.”

“How can you do it so fast?” Liam demanded, and he stumbled, but Crowley moved to catch him by the hand before he could tip too far the other way, letting him catch his balance again.

The children had been watching Crowley fix some of the tiling on the Halifax family’s roof on the other side of Chesterton-Burnleigh, and they’d been mystified by the way Crowley had moved so fast back and forth over the support beams and even over the railing on the edges of their balconies. Aziraphale would love to be able to chalk it up to his demonic grace, that perhaps he had his wings invisibly outstretched to assist him in balancing, but he knew that wasn’t the case: Crowley really was that comfortable on his fleet feet, balancing on thin beams and railings, and now he had set up a wooden beam on the picnic green beside the pond for them to try their own balance on. The grass here was thick and littered with daisies, and would provide a good deal of padding if they fell, beyond Crowley’s own little twists of magic.

He remembered, the body Crowley had had before this one. He’d lost it in… Oh, what year was it? 1831, he thought, that he’d been discorporated, and he’d only had it for sixty years or so. He preferred – like Aziraphale – to wear a man’s body, as a rule[1], but he’d worn a woman’s body, then. He’d been kicked by a horse, Aziraphale thought, that was what had ended it…

He’d been a nursemaid for quite a few families, before he’d gone on to teach at a girls’ school for ten years or so. He had always enjoyed the work, and Aziraphale had always thought he would be corrupting the children, but he never did, especially. The children were always very happy and healthy, and he was always very careful with them, even as he went about his usual duties. It was the best way, he always said at the time, for a young woman to remain unmarried and not in threat of such proposals, but Aziraphale had never really believed that.

Crowley could go unnoticed no matter whom or what he wore.

“It’s just practice,” Crowley was saying gently. “You get a sense for it.”

Crowley could go unnoticed no matter whom or what he wore.

[[MORE]]

Liam came to the end of the bar, taking a slow step down, and Crowley turned to gesture for young Lisa, who was the end of the line.

She crossed her arms over her chest. “It looks quite dangerous,” she said.

“It isn’t dangerous,” Crowley said, shaking his head. Aziraphale watched the way he moved. It came so instinctively to him, it always had: he leaned down just slightly, that him and Lisa were on a more similar level, but his body language was open and casual. Aziraphale wouldn’t have thought to do that, he didn’t think – or maybe he would have crouched, and Crowley said the children hated it when one did that. “Look, you’ve seen Liam, Stephanie, and Nathaniel do it, and when Nick fell, I caught him, didn’t I?”

“Yeah, but he’s small,” Lisa said. She was a rather large little girl, round where her sister was more athletic, and she looked rather anxious. “He’s not nearly as heavy as I am.”

Crowley smiled, and it was a warm, gentle smile, softly paternal in its aspect, and Aziraphale exhaled quietly at the sight of it. “Lisa, you are not heavy. You’ve seen me carry big sheets of glass, the stone for the benches… Darling, you’re a bag of feathers compared to all that.”

Lisa didn’t look convinced, biting down upon her lower lip, and Aziraphale hesitated, but then he set a bookmark on his page, taking a few steps forward.

“Why don’t I show you, dear?” he asked, and Lisa turned to look up at him. Aziraphale felt himself stiffen slightly, uncertain, but then Lisa gave an anxious smile, and nodded her head. She was the only one of the children who visited here he really felt he understood, although that was hardly saying much: he wasn’t very good with children, much as he tried his best, and he knew that, but Lisa didn’t seem to mind especially, and would sometimes come and sit down next to him whilst Crowley led the other children in an activity, or when she grew disinterested in Crowley’s lessons on one subject or other.

“You can’t do it,” Stephanie said as Aziraphale delicately toed off his loafers.

“And why is that, young lady?” Aziraphale asked as Crowley smiled at him, leaning forward and taking hold of his hand, bringing it up to his mouth and kissing the back of his knuckles.

“You’re old,” Stephanie said. “And— And—”

“Big?” Aziraphale asked, somewhat archly.

Stephanie closed her mouth. Aziraphale heard Lisa giggle behind him.

“You will catch me?” he asked, somewhat uncertainly.

“You probably won’t fall,” Crowley said, and Aziraphale laughed as he stepped up the wooden stair Crowley had laid beside the beam. It wasn’t so far off the ground – only a little higher than four feet – but he did feel somewhat unbalanced as he set one sole upon the beam, stretching out his arms and letting Crowley release his hand.

“Could you fix someone’s roof, Mr Fell?” Nick asked.

“Oh, goodness, no,” Aziraphale said, resisting the urge to shake his head, because he knew he would topple if he did that. He wanted to throw out his wings to assist him, but he didn’t wish to cheat, as it were: he was rather unsteady as he moved along the beam, rather slowly, compared to the children, but Crowley was smiling up at him as he walked alongside. “No, I fear Anthony far exceeds me in most practical skills.”

“That’s not true,” Crowley murmured. “Ezra can make bindings for books from scratch. Spins his goldwork and everything.”

“What’s goldwork?” Liam asked.

“You spin metals into thin threads,” Ezra said, focusing forward as he drew his next foot forward. “You can embroider with them, then – some books take well to embroidery to decorate covers, especially leather and cloth covers, but it’s very good for the binding, too, where one might stitch the pages. Golden or silver thread is quite hardwearing, of course.”

“Wow,” Liam said. Aziraphale felt his lips twitch as he finally came to the end of the beam. He’d had a few wobbles, but he hadn’t fallen—

Well.

Until now.

He turned to meet Crowley’s gaze, and the demon gave a slight inclination of his head: Aziraphale squeezed his eyes rather tightly shut as he let himself tip to the side, doing his best not to let out a yelp as he felt his foot come away from the bar, but he knew Crowley would catch him, he knew—

Crowley’s arms were strong as they encircled him, catching at the backs of his thighs and his back, and Aziraphale let out a breathless sound, reaching up and touching the side of Crowley’s neck. Crowley leaned in, kissing his nose, and Aziraphale laughed quietly, leaning his head on Crowley’s shoulder as he exhaled.

“See?” Crowley said, winking at Lisa. “Light as a feather.”

She did look much more confident now, at least. Aziraphale could see the light shining in her eyes and the way she was bouncing on her heels, and he felt himself smile slightly as he stood delicately back to his feet, moving to retrieve his shoes.

Lisa hurried forward, and Aziraphale stepped to the side, but to his surprise she threw her arms about his waist, hugging him very tightly. “Oh,” he said, awkwardly – but gently – patting the top of her head, brushing the blue silk of her Alice band as he did so, and he smiled.

“Thank you, Mr Fell,” she mumbled against the wool vest over his belly.

“Oh, my dear, it’s no trouble at all, come now.” He looked at Crowley, who raised his eyebrows and shrugged his shoulders slightly, but his smile was encouraging. Aziraphale delicately patted her shoulder, and she leaned back, beaming up at him, before she stepped toward the beam and removed her little ballet slippers.

It was—

He hadn’t been hugged by a child in an awfully long time, he didn’t think. He wasn’t sure in how many years, but not for… In the mid-19th century, perhaps, when Crowley was asleep – he’d taken up at the Hyacinth and Vine, the discreet little gentleman’s club in London, much more than he had, and he believed he’d fetched some young boy’s cat from a tree whilst walking out to the club of an evening. Poor thing had been beside himself, if he recalled.

This was somewhat more—

Significant, he supposed it felt.

They had been here for several months, now. Adam had visited twice, and that had been nice – they’d actually rather begun being his godfathers, in the year since the Apocalypse hadn’t happened, and he was a pleasant boy, kind, intelligent, but he was rather…

Crowley would no doubt chide him for calling the boy rough-and-tumble. Aziraphale didn’t know what the more modern parlance might be. But he didn’t especially need anybody’s support or comfort, and although he often asked Aziraphale questions, he didn’t ordinarily wait for an answer.

These children, though, they did listen to him, particularly when they asked for him to explain something. They could be a little rude, of course – Stephanie in particular had a rather startling tendency to blurt out precisely what was on her mind, regardless of how thoughtless it might be, and young Nathaniel tried too hard to be clever, sometimes with a view to being unkind, but… They weren’t nasty children, not at all. They were generally thoughtful, and generally gentle.

He recalled when Crowley had taught at that girls’ school – those young ladies had been vicious little demons in their own right, even without his careful tutelage. He liked children, Aziraphale knew. He was good with them, and they liked him: they liked that he was funny and erudite, and they liked how neatly he explained things, how he saw things on their level…

Aziraphale wasn’t all that good at such things. He condescended without meaning to, or got confused as to what the children did or didn’t know, or tried too hard. But, Crowley…

“There you go, my girl!” Crowley said, clapping his hands together, and Lisa laughed as she stepped on very graceful feet down from the beam – she really did have nothing to worry about. She was an incredibly dainty girl, with a grace that did remind Aziraphale of the way things used to be, seventy years ago, ninety…

She beamed at Aziraphale, and he smiled right back at her.

♔ ☩ ♔ ☩ ♔ ☩ ♔

Later on, when the children had gone home, he sat at one of the stools on the kitchen island, watching Crowley’s fingers as he delicately worked upon the pastry, twisting two threads of the stuff about the edge of a bramble pie.

“Crowley,” Aziraphale asked.

“Yeah?”

“With— With Young Warlock,” Aziraphale said quietly, keeping his hands up from the counter and away from the flour dusting it, “you sent Ashtoreth. In your place, I mean, as I sent Francis.”

“Ye-es,” Crowley said, raising an expectant eyebrow.

“But— Well, my dear, you were a nursemaid. For nearly fifty years! And that was without teaching at that boarding school, too.”

“Oh, that was years ago,” Crowley scoffed, his tone dismissive. “Children were different, then.”

“But these children are just the same, and you’re good with them,” Aziraphale said. “Teaching them this morning, you did so well with them. They adore you. I don’t mean to disparage Ashtoreth’s abilities, but had you nannied himself, you know, you’d have been— You’d have been at quite the advantage, you know, you could have…”

“We wanted it to be equal,” Crowley said. “Our influence.”

“Yes,” Aziraphale allowed.

“And I never—” Crowley furrowed his brow, pressing his lips together. “Ashtoreth was comfortable, going all in for that… Hell stuff. You know, telling him to praise Lucifer and what-not, and telling him to be nasty and cruel. What do I want to be telling a kid to do that for? She was just as— What is it, as Francis was? Over-the-top, it means.”

“Superlative?”

“Superlative,” Crowley said, nodding his head. “Yeah. I couldn’t have been like that.”

“You seem— My dear, you seem ever so happy. So in your element, with these children.”

“I am,” Crowley murmured, his lip twitching slightly, and Aziraphale reached out, drawing his fingers gently over Crowley’s chin, tracing the jut of bone there. “Can’t exactly win that Lisa Turpin over, though. She’s your girl through and through, Mr Fell.”

“Oh, I don’t know about that, Mr Crowley,” Aziraphale murmured, touching his thumb to the base of Crowley’s lip as Crowley looked at him with warmth in his yellow eyes, but he felt himself smile, felt the sense of warmth the idea evoked. “They’re such… They’re such lovely children. I just wish I had your grace with them.”

“You just need to let them come to you,” Crowley said. “Like cats.”

“A lot of cats find me overbearing,” Aziraphale said.

“Yeah,” Crowley said. “This advice is two birds with one stone, angel.”

Aziraphale let out an indignant huff, but Crowley leaned his chin right into Aziraphale’s palm, showing his teeth when he smiled again. “You know,” Aziraphale said, “and I don’t say this in terms of the, ah, the near future, but… A lot of retirees, they foster.”

“Something to think about,” Crowley said quietly, kissing the meat at the heel of Aziraphale’s palm. “Do you want to watch something? I’ll bring the television up to the bedroom.”

“What have you in mind?”

“Star Trek. The one with the whales, I picked it up on video.”

“We saw that in the cinema only a few years back.”

“Yeah, I know,” Crowley said.

Aziraphale considered this for a moment, his fingers stroking at the base of Crowley’s throat, feeling the smoothness of the skin. For just a moment, they were outside Eden, and Crowley was but a mess of roping coils in his lap, his scaled chin resting in Aziraphale’s palm. That was ever so long ago, and yet equally, it was just yesterday.

He nodded, with a small smile, and he withdrew his hand, that Crowley might return to his work.

They could be a little rude, of course – Stephanie in particular had a rather startling tendency to blurt out precisely what was on her mind, regardless of how thoughtless it might be, and young Nathaniel tried too hard to be clever, sometimes with a view to being unkind, but… They weren’t nasty children, not at all. They were generally thoughtful, and generally gentle.

He recalled when Crowley had taught at that girls’ school – those young ladies had been vicious little demons in their own right, even without his careful tutelage. He liked children, Aziraphale knew. He was good with them, and they liked him: they liked that he was funny and erudite, and they liked how neatly he explained things, how he saw things on their level…

Aziraphale wasn’t all that good at such things. He condescended without meaning to, or got confused as to what the children did or didn’t know, or tried too hard. But, Crowley…

“There you go, my girl!” Crowley said, clapping his hands together, and Lisa laughed as she stepped on very graceful feet down from the beam – she really did have nothing to worry about. She was an incredibly dainty girl, with a grace that did remind Aziraphale of the way things used to be, seventy years ago, ninety…

She beamed at Aziraphale, and he smiled right back at her.

♔ ☩ ♔ ☩ ♔ ☩ ♔

Later on, when the children had gone home, he sat at one of the stools on the kitchen island, watching Crowley’s fingers as he delicately worked upon the pastry, twisting two threads of the stuff about the edge of a bramble pie.

“Crowley,” Aziraphale asked.

“Yeah?”

“With— With Young Warlock,” Aziraphale said quietly, keeping his hands up from the counter and away from the flour dusting it, “you sent Ashtoreth. In your place, I mean, as I sent Francis.”

“Ye-es,” Crowley said, raising an expectant eyebrow.

“But— Well, my dear, you were a nursemaid. For nearly fifty years! And that was without teaching at that boarding school, too.”

“Oh, that was years ago,” Crowley scoffed, his tone dismissive. “Children were different, then.”

“But these children are just the same, and you’re good with them,” Aziraphale said. “Teaching them this morning, you did so well with them. They adore you. I don’t mean to disparage Ashtoreth’s abilities, but had you nannied himself, you know, you’d have been— You’d have been at quite the advantage, you know, you could have…”

“We wanted it to be equal,” Crowley said. “Our influence.”

“Yes,” Aziraphale allowed.

“And I never—” Crowley furrowed his brow, pressing his lips together. “Ashtoreth was comfortable, going all in for that… Hell stuff. You know, telling him to praise Lucifer and what-not, and telling him to be nasty and cruel. What do I want to be telling a kid to do that for? She was just as— What is it, as Francis was? Over-the-top, it means.”

“Superlative?”

“Superlative,” Crowley said, nodding his head. “Yeah. I couldn’t have been like that.”

“You seem— My dear, you seem ever so happy. So in your element, with these children.”

“I am,” Crowley murmured, his lip twitching slightly, and Aziraphale reached out, drawing his fingers gently over Crowley’s chin, tracing the jut of bone there. “Can’t exactly win that Lisa Turpin over, though. She’s your girl through and through, Mr Fell.”

“Oh, I don’t know about that, Mr Crowley,” Aziraphale murmured, touching his thumb to the base of Crowley’s lip as Crowley looked at him with warmth in his yellow eyes, but he felt himself smile, felt the sense of warmth the idea evoked. “They’re such… They’re such lovely children. I just wish I had your grace with them.”

“You just need to let them come to you,” Crowley said. “Like cats.”

“A lot of cats find me overbearing,” Aziraphale said.

“Yeah,” Crowley said. “This advice is two birds with one stone, angel.”

Aziraphale let out an indignant huff, but Crowley leaned his chin right into Aziraphale’s palm, showing his teeth when he smiled again. “You know,” Aziraphale said, “and I don’t say this in terms of the, ah, the near future, but… A lot of retirees, they foster.”

“Something to think about,” Crowley said quietly, kissing the meat at the heel of Aziraphale’s palm. “Do you want to watch something? I’ll bring the television up to the bedroom.”

“What have you in mind?”

“Star Trek. The one with the whales, I picked it up on video.”

“We saw that in the cinema only a few years back.”

“Yeah, I know,” Crowley said.

Aziraphale considered this for a moment, his fingers stroking at the base of Crowley’s throat, feeling the smoothness of the skin. For just a moment, they were outside Eden, and Crowley was but a mess of roping coils in his lap, his scaled chin resting in Aziraphale’s palm. That was ever so long ago, and yet equally, it was just yesterday.

He nodded, with a small smile, and he withdrew his hand, that Crowley might return to his work.

It was a good night.

Peaceful, quiet.

They were at home together, and this was the new routine.

[1] Although, they would each freely admit, this mattered very little, as either of them could alter their appearance quite entirely on the head of a pin, if they wanted to, but it was the premise of the thing.

“That’s alright, just like that,” Crowley said, smiling as he leaned back, and Aziraphale kept his book loosely in his lap as he watched Crowley work. Liam had his arms outstretched as he walked slowly along the bar, his gaze forward. “No, no, see, you’re going on your tiptoes again – you don’t need to. You’ve got the whole of your sole to help you balance, lad, so your toes and your heel… That’s it.”

“How can you do it so fast?” Liam demanded, and he stumbled, but Crowley moved to catch him by the hand before he could tip too far the other way, letting him catch his balance again.

The children had been watching Crowley fix some of the tiling on the Halifax family’s roof on the other side of Chesterton-Burnleigh, and they’d been mystified by the way Crowley had moved so fast back and forth over the support beams and even over the railing on the edges of their balconies. Aziraphale would love to be able to chalk it up to his demonic grace, that perhaps he had his wings invisibly outstretched to assist him in balancing, but he knew that wasn’t the case: Crowley really was that comfortable on his fleet feet, balancing on thin beams and railings, and now he had set up a wooden beam on the picnic green beside the pond for them to try their own balance on. The grass here was thick and littered with daisies, and would provide a good deal of padding if they fell, beyond Crowley’s own little twists of magic.

He remembered, the body Crowley had had before this one. He’d lost it in… Oh, what year was it? 1831, he thought, that he’d been discorporated, and he’d only had it for sixty years or so. He preferred – like Aziraphale – to wear a man’s body, as a rule[1], but he’d worn a woman’s body, then. He’d been kicked by a horse, Aziraphale thought, that was what had ended it…

He’d been a nursemaid for quite a few families, before he’d gone on to teach at a girls’ school for ten years or so. He had always enjoyed the work, and Aziraphale had always thought he would be corrupting the children, but he never did, especially. The children were always very happy and healthy, and he was always very careful with them, even as he went about his usual duties. It was the best way, he always said at the time, for a young woman to remain unmarried and not in threat of such proposals, but Aziraphale had never really believed that.

Crowley could go unnoticed no matter whom or what he wore.

“It’s just practice,” Crowley was saying gently. “You get a sense for it.”

Liam came to the end of the bar, taking a slow step down, and Crowley turned to gesture for young Lisa, who was the end of the line.

She crossed her arms over her chest. “It looks quite dangerous,” she said.

“It isn’t dangerous,” Crowley said, shaking his head. Aziraphale watched the way he moved. It came so instinctively to him, it always had: he leaned down just slightly, that him and Lisa were on a more similar level, but his body language was open and casual. Aziraphale wouldn’t have thought to do that, he didn’t think – or maybe he would have crouched, and Crowley said the children hated it when one did that. “Look, you’ve seen Liam, Stephanie, and Nathaniel do it, and when Nick fell, I caught him, didn’t I?”

“Yeah, but he’s small,” Lisa said. She was a rather large little girl, round where her sister was more athletic, and she looked rather anxious. “He’s not nearly as heavy as I am.”

Crowley smiled, and it was a warm, gentle smile, softly paternal in its aspect, and Aziraphale exhaled quietly at the sight of it. “Lisa, you are not heavy. You’ve seen me carry big sheets of glass, the stone for the benches… Darling, you’re a bag of feathers compared to all that.”

Lisa didn’t look convinced, biting down upon her lower lip, and Aziraphale hesitated, but then he set a bookmark on his page, taking a few steps forward.

“Why don’t I show you, dear?” he asked, and Lisa turned to look up at him. Aziraphale felt himself stiffen slightly, uncertain, but then Lisa gave an anxious smile, and nodded her head. She was the only one of the children who visited here he really felt he understood, although that was hardly saying much: he wasn’t very good with children, much as he tried his best, and he knew that, but Lisa didn’t seem to mind especially, and would sometimes come and sit down next to him whilst Crowley led the other children in an activity, or when she grew disinterested in Crowley’s lessons on one subject or other.

“You can’t do it,” Stephanie said as Aziraphale delicately toed off his loafers.

“And why is that, young lady?” Aziraphale asked as Crowley smiled at him, leaning forward and taking hold of his hand, bringing it up to his mouth and kissing the back of his knuckles.

“You’re old,” Stephanie said. “And— And—”

“Big?” Aziraphale asked, somewhat archly.

Stephanie closed her mouth. Aziraphale heard Lisa giggle behind him.

“You will catch me?” he asked, somewhat uncertainly.

“You probably won’t fall,” Crowley said, and Aziraphale laughed as he stepped up the wooden stair Crowley had laid beside the beam. It wasn’t so far off the ground – only a little higher than four feet – but he did feel somewhat unbalanced as he set one sole upon the beam, stretching out his arms and letting Crowley release his hand.

“Could you fix someone’s roof, Mr Fell?” Nick asked.

“Oh, goodness, no,” Aziraphale said, resisting the urge to shake his head, because he knew he would topple if he did that. He wanted to throw out his wings to assist him, but he didn’t wish to cheat, as it were: he was rather unsteady as he moved along the beam, rather slowly, compared to the children, but Crowley was smiling up at him as he walked alongside. “No, I fear Anthony far exceeds me in most practical skills.”

“That’s not true,” Crowley murmured. “Ezra can make bindings for books from scratch. Spins his goldwork and everything.”

“What’s goldwork?” Liam asked.

“You spin metals into thin threads,” Ezra said, focusing forward as he drew his next foot forward. “You can embroider with them, then – some books take well to embroidery to decorate covers, especially leather and cloth covers, but it’s very good for the binding, too, where one might stitch the pages. Golden or silver thread is quite hardwearing, of course.”

“Wow,” Liam said. Aziraphale felt his lips twitch as he finally came to the end of the beam. He’d had a few wobbles, but he hadn’t fallen—

Well.

Until now.

He turned to meet Crowley’s gaze, and the demon gave a slight inclination of his head: Aziraphale squeezed his eyes rather tightly shut as he let himself tip to the side, doing his best not to let out a yelp as he felt his foot come away from the bar, but he knew Crowley would catch him, he knew—

Crowley’s arms were strong as they encircled him, catching at the backs of his thighs and his back, and Aziraphale let out a breathless sound, reaching up and touching the side of Crowley’s neck. Crowley leaned in, kissing his nose, and Aziraphale laughed quietly, leaning his head on Crowley’s shoulder as he exhaled.

“See?” Crowley said, winking at Lisa. “Light as a feather.”

She did look much more confident now, at least. Aziraphale could see the light shining in her eyes and the way she was bouncing on her heels, and he felt himself smile slightly as he stood delicately back to his feet, moving to retrieve his shoes.

Lisa hurried forward, and Aziraphale stepped to the side, but to his surprise she threw her arms about his waist, hugging him very tightly. “Oh,” he said, awkwardly – but gently – patting the top of her head, brushing the blue silk of her Alice band as he did so, and he smiled.

“Thank you, Mr Fell,” she mumbled against the wool vest over his belly.

“Oh, my dear, it’s no trouble at all, come now.” He looked at Crowley, who raised his eyebrows and shrugged his shoulders slightly, but his smile was encouraging. Aziraphale delicately patted her shoulder, and she leaned back, beaming up at him, before she stepped toward the beam and removed her little ballet slippers.

It was—

He hadn’t been hugged by a child in an awfully long time, he didn’t think. He wasn’t sure in how many years, but not for… In the mid-19th century, perhaps, when Crowley was asleep – he’d taken up at the Hyacinth and Vine, the discreet little gentleman’s club in London, much more than he had, and he believed he’d fetched some young boy’s cat from a tree whilst walking out to the club of an evening. Poor thing had been beside himself, if he recalled.

This was somewhat more—

Significant, he supposed it felt.

They had been here for several months, now. Adam had visited twice, and that had been nice – they’d actually rather begun being his godfathers, in the year since the Apocalypse hadn’t happened, and he was a pleasant boy, kind, intelligent, but he was rather…

Crowley would no doubt chide him for calling the boy rough-and-tumble. Aziraphale didn’t know what the more modern parlance might be. But he didn’t especially need anybody’s support or comfort, and although he often asked Aziraphale questions, he didn’t ordinarily wait for an answer.

They could be a little rude, of course – Stephanie in particular had a rather startling tendency to blurt out precisely what was on her mind, regardless of how thoughtless it might be, and young Nathaniel tried too hard to be clever, sometimes with a view to being unkind, but… They weren’t nasty children, not at all. They were generally thoughtful, and generally gentle.

He recalled when Crowley had taught at that girls’ school – those young ladies had been vicious little demons in their own right, even without his careful tutelage. He liked children, Aziraphale knew. He was good with them, and they liked him: they liked that he was funny and erudite, and they liked how neatly he explained things, how he saw things on their level…

Aziraphale wasn’t all that good at such things. He condescended without meaning to, or got confused as to what the children did or didn’t know, or tried too hard. But, Crowley…

“There you go, my girl!” Crowley said, clapping his hands together, and Lisa laughed as she stepped on very graceful feet down from the beam – she really did have nothing to worry about. She was an incredibly dainty girl, with a grace that did remind Aziraphale of the way things used to be, seventy years ago, ninety…

She beamed at Aziraphale, and he smiled right back at her.

♔ ☩ ♔ ☩ ♔ ☩ ♔

Later on, when the children had gone home, he sat at one of the stools on the kitchen island, watching Crowley’s fingers as he delicately worked upon the pastry, twisting two threads of the stuff about the edge of a bramble pie.

“Crowley,” Aziraphale asked.

“Yeah?”

“With— With Young Warlock,” Aziraphale said quietly, keeping his hands up from the counter and away from the flour dusting it, “you sent Ashtoreth. In your place, I mean, as I sent Francis.”

“Ye-es,” Crowley said, raising an expectant eyebrow.

“But— Well, my dear, you were a nursemaid. For nearly fifty years! And that was without teaching at that boarding school, too.”

“Oh, that was years ago,” Crowley scoffed, his tone dismissive. “Children were different, then.”

“But these children are just the same, and you’re good with them,” Aziraphale said. “Teaching them this morning, you did so well with them. They adore you. I don’t mean to disparage Ashtoreth’s abilities, but had you nannied himself, you know, you’d have been— You’d have been at quite the advantage, you know, you could have…”

“We wanted it to be equal,” Crowley said. “Our influence.”

“Yes,” Aziraphale allowed.

“And I never—” Crowley furrowed his brow, pressing his lips together. “Ashtoreth was comfortable, going all in for that… Hell stuff. You know, telling him to praise Lucifer and what-not, and telling him to be nasty and cruel. What do I want to be telling a kid to do that for? She was just as— What is it, as Francis was? Over-the-top, it means.”

“Superlative?”

“Superlative,” Crowley said, nodding his head. “Yeah. I couldn’t have been like that.”

“You seem— My dear, you seem ever so happy. So in your element, with these children.”

“I am,” Crowley murmured, his lip twitching slightly, and Aziraphale reached out, drawing his fingers gently over Crowley’s chin, tracing the jut of bone there. “Can’t exactly win that Lisa Turpin over, though. She’s your girl through and through, Mr Fell.”

“Something to think about,” Crowley said quietly, kissing the meat at the heel of Aziraphale’s palm. “Do you want to watch something? I’ll bring the television up to the bedroom.”

☆ bi-aro, multifandom, she/her, Filipino ★

summary: in lieu of Aziraphale Pulling Breadcrumbs Out Of His Top Hat I give you--
body:
in lieu of Aziraphale Pulling Breadcrumbs Out Of His Top Hat I give you–

the Aziraphale Does Not Use Objects For Their Intended Uses Because He Genuinely Does Not Understand Their Intended Use™️ bullet point headcanons:

  • I know that that little bit was put in perhaps as foreshadowing for his magic show later on but I am also under the impression that…
  • He simply stores food in his top hat. We know that. We’ve seen it. He doesn’t understand why it has so much room with such a tiny brim. But there is so much space inside, perhaps it is made to be storage? Pastries and sandwiches. Sometimes a biscuit or two. The crumbs in his otherwise immaculate hair is just a small price to pay.
  • He is not flexible– must we remind you that Crowley is the snake, not he? Oh no, his arms cannot reach behind him relieve himself of that dreadful itch. It’s why he uses a wooden spoon. In fact, he keeps it close and it goes everywhere with him around the shop and the flat. Anywhere but the kitchen.
  • He has a trumpet hanging from one of the bookshelves in his shop. He doesn’t play. It’s his special vase– there are new fresh flowers in there every other day (courtesy of a rather amorous serpent) and it’s mouthpiece never drips water even if it probably should. (Crowley suspects Azira does to objects what he does to plants– except politely, of course. And nicer. That trumpet is so well behaved.)
  • He does not fold the pages of books. But he owns no bookmarks. Crowley has once found a sock pressed into the pages of an original copy of the Divine Comedy.
  • Crowley’s taken to giving him cassettes instead of Vinyls or CDs– both tend to end up as coasters or chargers at one point. It’s horrendous.
  • The gramophone has birds nesting in it. Crowley doesn’t even know how they got in there. He despairs.
  • A fork? To comb his wings? That he had started using because the brush was too far away? Oh, you bet.
  • No wonder they’re so ill-kept.
  • Crowley gave him a mobile phone at one point. And at one point he had found it in the refrigerator. Where all his other gifts to Azira that he does not use are stored.
  • Crowley had bought him an iPad once. He’d used it as a tray for hot cocoa.
  • He.
  • Sits.
  • On.
  • Top.
  • Of.
  • Anything.
  • Including a chair, the top of said refrigerator, on top of shelves and on dangerously teetering piles of books.
  • You’d think Crowley is bad. Azira is worse. At least Crowley does it in snake form and because he’s a cheeky bastard. Azira does it because he genuinely thinks it’s acceptable.
  • Pencils he uses like thumbtacks. They intimidate customers, when they come in and find an otherwise mild mannered man drive a pencil into the wall just to hang a flier of nonsense all the while making intense eye contact. But it’s become a habit. Crowley refuses to buy him any more pencils.
  • That’s alright. He does it with pens, too.

  • He has a trumpet hanging from one of the bookshelves in his shop. He doesn’t play. It’s his special vase– there are new fresh flowers in there every other day (courtesy of a rather amorous serpent) and it’s mouthpiece never drips water even if it probably should. (Crowley suspects Azira does to objects what he does to plants– except politely, of course. And nicer. That trumpet is so well behaved.)
  • He does not fold the pages of books. But he owns no bookmarks. Crowley has once found a sock pressed into the pages of an original copy of the Divine Comedy.
  • Crowley’s taken to giving him cassettes instead of Vinyls or CDs– both tend to end up as coasters or chargers at one point. It’s horrendous.
  • The gramophone has birds nesting in it. Crowley doesn’t even know how they got in there. He despairs.
  • A fork? To comb his wings? That he had started using because the brush was too far away? Oh, you bet.
  • No wonder they’re so ill-kept.
  • Crowley gave him a mobile phone at one point. And at one point he had found it in the refrigerator. Where all his other gifts to Azira that he does not use are stored.
  • Crowley had bought him an iPad once. He’d used it as a tray for hot cocoa.
  • He.
  • Sits.
  • On.
  • Top.
  • Of.
  • Anything.
  • Including a chair, the top of said refrigerator, on top of shelves and on dangerously teetering piles of books.
  • You’d think Crowley is bad. Azira is worse. At least Crowley does it in snake form and because he’s a cheeky bastard. Azira does it because he genuinely thinks it’s acceptable.
  • Pencils he uses like thumbtacks. They intimidate customers, when they come in and find an otherwise mild mannered man drive a pencil into the wall just to hang a flier of nonsense all the while making intense eye contact. But it’s become a habit. Crowley refuses to buy him any more pencils.
  • That’s alright. He does it with pens, too.
trail.content:
in lieu of Aziraphale Pulling Breadcrumbs Out Of His Top Hat I give you–

the Aziraphale Does Not Use Objects For Their Intended Uses Because He Genuinely Does Not Understand Their Intended Use™️ bullet point headcanons:

  • I know that that little bit was put in perhaps as foreshadowing for his magic show later on but I am also under the impression that…
  • He simply stores food in his top hat. We know that. We’ve seen it. He doesn’t understand why it has so much room with such a tiny brim. But there is so much space inside, perhaps it is made to be storage? Pastries and sandwiches. Sometimes a biscuit or two. The crumbs in his otherwise immaculate hair is just a small price to pay.
  • He is not flexible– must we remind you that Crowley is the snake, not he? Oh no, his arms cannot reach behind him relieve himself of that dreadful itch. It’s why he uses a wooden spoon. He did...
body:
Headcanon that Aziraphale has many variations of ‘Live, Laugh, Love’ plaques and pillows and things all over his house.

He did however, refuse to put up the crosstich of “Hell, Sweet Hell’ that Crowley made to wind him up. But he doesn’t have the heart to get rid of it because it would have taken time and effort on Crowley’s part.
